componenttext: Lazard Capital Markets. First, let me say that the Legacy assortment looks amazing, so I can see why you guys are so excited about it. And then just a quick clarification, just want to make sure I heard correctly. Comps at Full Price stores in the fourth quarter increased around 6.7%, right?

headline: Coach, Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: What we said was that they remain consistent with their level last year. We do not -- last quarter. We do not disaggregate comps. And our overall comps were 6.7% in the third quarter. And what we went on to say was that the entire decline was due to a dec
componenttext: What we said was that they remain consistent with their level last year. We do not -- last quarter. We do not disaggregate comps. And our overall comps were 6.7% in the third quarter. And what we went on to say was that the entire decline was due to a decline in performance within our factory channel during the fourth quarter.

headline: Coach, Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then my question is for Mike Tucci. Just wondering what your thoughts are on the North American wholesale business, now that you're in charge of that business as well. Do you think that there are any changes to the strategy maybe that you
componenttext: Okay, great. And then my question is for Mike Tucci. Just wondering what your thoughts are on the North American wholesale business, now that you're in charge of that business as well. Do you think that there are any changes to the strategy maybe that you could make there?

headline: Coach, Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: I do. Quick learnings there for me. One, we have a strong team here with great relationships with our key partners in the department stores. The department store leaders are very committed to Coach. We're working extremely hard to create the same exciteme
componenttext: I do. Quick learnings there for me. One, we have a strong team here with great relationships with our key partners in the department stores. The department store leaders are very committed to Coach. We're working extremely hard to create the same excitement around Legacy in department stores that we have in our retail stores. And so the investment that we're making around presentation, product assortment, training and development and marketing really carries over into the wholesale channel. That launch was timed exactly to the day with -- when we launched in our retail stores. I think the first major flagship in a department store that's going to be run by the Coach direct team in Herald Square as part of the accessories hall that Macy's is doing in New York is a tremendous opportunity for us and one that we may find some opportunities for a longer term in terms of the operating model. So we're working very hard on that channel to protect our position there as a market share leader and to deliver value to that consumer.

headline: Coach, Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2012

componenttext: Crédit Suisse. I was wondering if you could talk a bit about the marketing investments and the cadence you expect there over the course of fiscal '13, and how that's going to impact the P&L?

componenttextpreview: Yes. So the marketing investments that we're talking about overall will be more front-end loaded. As we talked about we are distorting our marketing early in the year to support Legacy so you will see it, especially in the first quarter. And as we move th
componenttext: Yes. So the marketing investments that we're talking about overall will be more front-end loaded. As we talked about we are distorting our marketing early in the year to support Legacy so you will see it, especially in the first quarter. And as we move through the year, we will be investing through the year. In aggregate, our incremental marketing investment we're expecting to be about $0.04 to EPS, a little more than $0.04 to EPS.

headline: Coach, Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's very helpful. Wondering if you could also talk about the concession shop with Macy's and what the thinking is there and whether that might become a model on a go-forward basis for North America?
componenttext: Okay. That's very helpful. Wondering if you could also talk about the concession shop with Macy's and what the thinking is there and whether that might become a model on a go-forward basis for North America?

headline: Coach, Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: Let me begin by saying that outside the U.S., all of our shop-in-shops are leased shops. These are -- they are all concession shops where we pay based on performance and, in some cases, a guaranteed minimum threshold. So this is really the prevailing mode
componenttext: Let me begin by saying that outside the U.S., all of our shop-in-shops are leased shops. These are -- they are all concession shops where we pay based on performance and, in some cases, a guaranteed minimum threshold. So this is really the prevailing model outside the United States, and we've enjoyed great success with that model. In the U.S., the situation is quite different, as department stores have maintained their direct operation of virtually all of their shops. We don't expect that to change materially. We see Macy's as an exceptional situation. We're partnering with Macy's to really create a global flagship for Coach that will attract tourists, both from the United States and abroad, to Macy's to see our spectacular shop.

headline: Coach, Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2012

componenttext: Thank you. That’s going to conclude our conference call today. We went a little longer than usual to make up for some of early technical difficulties. But now, I'd like to turn it back over to Lew for a few closing words. Lew?

headline: Coach, Inc., Q4 2012 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2012
componenttextpreview: Let me begin by saying that we know there's a lot of interest in what we announced today. Obviously, some of the metrics were lower than what Wall Street expected. The reality is that we manage our business for the long term, and we have real clarity abou
componenttext: Let me begin by saying that we know there's a lot of interest in what we announced today. Obviously, some of the metrics were lower than what Wall Street expected. The reality is that we manage our business for the long term, and we have real clarity about what we're doing and where we're traveling and are very confident in our long-term growth prospects and our ability to drive our business at a double-digit pace. We have an exceptionally strong franchise. We have a seasoned and nimble management team and operating team, and we're driven to win. And I believe that you will find that in the seasons and years to come, we will prevail as we have over the years and decades. Thank you, everybody.

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Coach Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I'd like to turn the call over to Senior Vice President of Investor Relations and Corporate Communications at Coach, M
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Coach Conference Call. Today's call is being recorded. At this time, for opening remarks and introductions, I'd like to turn the call over to Senior Vice President of Investor Relations and Corporate Communications at Coach, Ms. Andrea Shaw Resnick. You may begin.

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us. With me today to discuss our quarterly results are Lew Frankfort, Coach's Chairman, CEO; and Jane Nielsen, Coach's CFO. Mike Tucci, North American Group President is also joining us for a holiday preview.Befor
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us. With me today to discuss our quarterly results are Lew Frankfort, Coach's Chairman, CEO; and Jane Nielsen, Coach's CFO. Mike Tucci, North American Group President is also joining us for a holiday preview.
Before we begin, we must point out that this conference call will involve certain forward-looking statements, including projections for our business in the current or future quarters or fiscal years. These statements are based upon a number of continuing assumptions. Future results may differ materially from our current expectations based upon risks and uncertainties such as expected economic trends or our ability to anticipate consumer preferences. Please refer to our latest annual report on Form 10-K and our quarterly report on Form 10-Q for the quarterly period ended December 31, 2011 for a complete list of these risk factors. Also, please note that historical growth trends may not be indicative of future growth.
Now let me highlight the speakers and topics for this conference call. Lew Frankfort will provide an overall summary of our first fiscal quarter 2013 results and will also discuss our program -- progress on global initiatives. Mike Tucci will review programs for the holiday season. Jane Nielsen will conclude with details and financial and operational highlights for the quarter. Following that, we will hold a question-and-answer session where we will be joined by Victor Luis, International Group President; and Jerry Stritzke, our President and Chief Operating Officer. The Q&A session will end shortly before 9:30 a.m. We will then conclude with some brief summary comments.
I'd now like to do this Lew Frankfort, Coach's Chairman and CEO.

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Thanks, Andrea, and welcome, everyone. As we noted in our press release, we were pleased with our results this quarter, highlighted by double-digit top line growth, with strong comparable store sales, most notably in North America and China.
componenttext:
Good morning. Thanks, Andrea, and welcome, everyone. As we noted in our press release, we were pleased with our results this quarter, highlighted by double-digit top line growth, with strong comparable store sales, most notably in North America and China. We continue to make progress against our strategic initiatives, enhancing our leadership position in the North American Women's bag and accessory category through fashion innovation, aggressively growing our International business, becoming a market leader in the Men's accessory category and harnessing the power of the digital world.
In addition, during the quarter, we completed the acquisition of our domestic distributors in Korea and Malaysia, and reflective of our strong balance sheet and positive outlook, our board has just authorized a new $1.5 billion stock repurchase authorization. While I will get into further detail about current conditions and the outlook for our business shortly, I did want to take the time to review our quarter first. Some highlights were, first, net sales totaled $1.16 billion versus $1.05 billion a year ago, an increase of 11%; second, earnings per share totaled $0.77, up 6% from the prior year; third, North American sales increased 8% to $784 million from $729 million last year, with direct sales up 11% on a 5.5% comparable store sales increase; and fourth, international sales increased 15% to $362 million from $314 million last year, driven in part by a nearly 40% gain in sales in China with a continuation of double-digit comps.
Looking first at global distribution. During the quarter, we opened 5 North American factory stores, including 3 Men's stores. At the end of the period, there were 354 full price and 174 factory stores in operation in North America.
Moving on to China. During the quarter, we opened 8 net new locations, one in Hong Kong, and the remainder on the Mainland, bringing the total number  to 104 locations, including 86 on the Mainland in 38 cities. In the wake of our recent Asia distributor acquisitions and including Singapore and Taiwan, which we took over last year, we now directly operate 92 locations in Asia, not including Japan and China. They include: 7 in Singapore, 10 in Malaysia, 27 in Taiwan and 48 in Korea. And in Japan, one Men's factory store is opened. At quarter end, there were 188 total locations in Japan with 23 standalone full priced stores, including 8 flagships, 122 shop-in-shops, 36 factory stores and 7 distributor operated wholesale locations.
Moving on to sales of productivity and starting in North America, which to-date represents about 2/3 of Coach's sales. Our total revenues in North America rose 8% for the quarter, while our directly operated business is up 11% technology. As noted, total Q1 same-store sales rose 5.5%, with our factory store comps benefiting from a return to more promotional in-store practices, and our full priced store comp similar to prior quarter trends. Of course, our Internet business, driven by significant traffic gains, continue to drive overall comp. In the department stores, sales trends POS was essentially even with prior year, while shipments into department stores declined as inventories were planned lower.
Overall, we estimate the addressable Women's North American handbag and accessory category rose about 10% last quarter. At the same time, in our own North American stores and on the Internet, Coach's sales rose 11%. It's worth noting that our Men's business was also a significant driver of our overall sales growth in Q1.
Moving on to the international sales, which represent about 1/3 of Coach's total sales today, they rose 15% in the first quarter. China sales rose nearly 40% from prior year, fueled by distribution and double-digit same-store sales. Clearly, the Chinese consumer has embraced Coach as evidenced by these results, as well as the increasing contribution of the Chinese tourists to our global sales in the extremely high purchase, repurchase intent among existing consumers. 
Our other Asia direct businesses outside of China and Japan, Singapore, Taiwan, Malaysia and Korea, also posted strong aggregate growth in the quarter. In part, these countries benefited from the retail step up from prior year except for Singapore, which was purchased at the beginning of last fiscal year. In addition, their combined POS sales also rose at a double-digit rate. In Japan, we posted a 1% increase in constant currency, while sales in dollars were even with prior year. Coach holds a #2 place within the Japanese imports accessories market, with a 17% yen share. Our position reflects the strength and relevance of the Coach brand with the Japanese consumer who has become increasingly value-oriented. 
Finally, I would like to touch on our international wholesale business where we experienced strong shipment growth as retail sales gains were driven by distribution expansion. While Jane will get into more detail on our financials and I will discuss our outlook in some detail shortly, I did want to give you this recap. As you know, Mike Tucci has joined us today to discuss our product performance for the first quarter, as well as our holiday sales initiative. Mike?

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lew. During the first quarter, we featured a high level of product innovation and distinctive newness, driven by our Legacy launch. We were very pleased by the excellent response to the collection as Legacy proved to resonate with consumers across
componenttext:
Thanks, Lew. During the first quarter, we featured a high level of product innovation and distinctive newness, driven by our Legacy launch. We were very pleased by the excellent response to the collection as Legacy proved to resonate with consumers across geographies and demographic. Inspired by our archives and featuring the carryall style, Legacy underscores our heritage as an authentic leather goods brand, distinctively Coach and differentiated in the marketplace. While Madison and Poppy remained important collections during the quarter, we continue to build our Legacy momentum over the next several months. Additional seasonal offerings such as cold weather and Outerwear are being introduced this quarter, along with new brights, novelty element such as awful lot and color block. Of course, we are supporting the collection with innovative marketing programs were just launch Grand Central take over here in New York, with 84 Coach images focused on the Northeast corridor of the station over 4-week period. We're also taking over buses and telephone kiosks in both New York and Chicago during fall and holiday.
Additionally, our recently updated Madison collection featured new silhouettes, including the J fact, and the new carryall, which will deliver an early December. New Poppy will arrive just in time for holiday and will feature our much loved iconic Willis bag in beautiful colors, color block and a range of great sizes and shapes. 
And of course, we'll also have a comprehensive assortment of great gifts from tech accessories to and wristlets and a wide range of items under $100 as well. In addition, our holiday product will be supported by comprehensive marketing plan beginning in mid-November, featuring a powerful gift a message. The emphasis of our marketing will be product and item-driven across our core categories and other gifting ideas. Our campaign will span coach.com, social and media advertising and compelling print and in-store marketing to drive traffic.
And our PR team working in conjunction with several of today's leading style authorities has developed a series of digitally-based initiatives centered around their favorite picks for holidays. Additionally, each of these style icons will curate designated shops of their holiday selections on coach.com.
I'd like to provide an updated on our Men's growth strategy, which is a significant opportunity for Coach, both here and North America where we have a long history of Men's leather goods resource and globally, where the category is more developed. During the last quarter, we added a broader assortment of Men's to an additional 14 full priced stores in North America, taking us to over 100 stores with a significant Men's presence by the end of September. We're seeing excellent response to our product, both in these retail stores and in our dedicated factory stores. Coach is rapidly becoming a leading brand authority in Men's bags and accessories. As we created the world of Coach for women across categories, we are now doing the same for men, designing collections with a distinct point of view, which sharing the modern classic as static that is the hallmark of Coach.
Moving to our stores, as part of our brand building initiatives, there's an opportunity both on our full price and factory stores to continue to elevate our store environments and to present a broader expression of Coach to our consumers. During the first quarter, to support Legacy, we rolled out new visual merchandising elements to about 100 retail stores and several key U.S. department store doors as well. These stores outperformed during the quarter, and we will continue to push these enhancements to more stores over the fiscal year. 
We've also experienced excellent customer response to our new 625 North Michigan Avenue flagship store in Chicago, which represents a new evolution of our retail concept and our new dual gender side-by-side concept store in Pentagon City Center. And just last week, we opened our first North America department store concession shop at Macy's Herald Square here in New York City. Designed by renowned architect Rem Koolhaas, this flagship space reflects our newest and most modern design elements, including video and digital content. That provides an elevated environment to showcase our product and enhance the Coach experience within the department store. On the factory side, our store elevation and its enhancement strategy was piloted in our Riverhead and Woodberry common stores with excellent results. We will roll this program out to about 25 of our highest volume stores by mid-November prior to our peak holiday selling season.
In summary, we will continue to drive our Women's business through fashion innovation, leverage the opportunity in Men's and evolve our store and digital concepts to provide a brand-right shopping experience for our consumer, wherever she chooses to shop. 
With that, I'll turn it back to Lew for a discussion of our strategy and further opportunities for growth. Lew?

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. Mike just discussed that the number of our brand building and productivity initiatives, which will be a significant contributor to top line sales in the season and years ahead, both in North America and international markets. Looking towards
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike. Mike just discussed that the number of our brand building and productivity initiatives, which will be a significant contributor to top line sales in the season and years ahead, both in North America and international markets. Looking towards the balance of FY '13, our overarching strategies remained largely unchanged. First, we're leveraging the global opportunity by aggressively growing our international businesses through both distribution expansion and productivity gains. Second, continuing to enhance our leadership position in the North America Women's bag accessory market, as we strengthen our position in lifestyle categories such as footwear. Third, we're tapping into the large and rapidly growing Men's accessory category, which Mike has already discussed. And fourth, we're harnessing the growing power of the digital world.
Starting with distribution. First, as our plans haven't changed materially from what we outlined on the July earnings call, I will be brief. To start, we expected that our square footage globally and across all channels will increase about 10% or 11% during this year. In North America, we now expect to add about 25 net new stores, including 20 factory stores, of which 10 will be Men's standalone location. 
Turning to international, and starting with China. We again expect to open about 30 new stores this year, bringing the total to around 125 locations by year's end. All of these openings are planned to be dual-gender stores due to the size of the Men's opportunity. In total, square footage in China is expected to grow about 35%. And as we said earlier, we expect sales to total at least $400 million, driven by both distribution and same location sales growth.
We were also very excited to announce a new distribution channel for China, e-commerce, which we expect to go live next month, providing Chinese consumers a new way to engage with the Coach brand. 
In terms of our other Asian direct markets, our primary focus this year is on driving productivity rather than new distribution as we continue to invest in people through training, as well as merchandising, store environment and systems, creating a brand-right experience. In Japan, where the overall consumer market remains challenging, we expect to open about 10 net new locations, most of them dedicated Men's doors. In total, we expect that net square footage growth will increase by about 10% this year compared to about 5% in FY '12.
Finally, as you know, beyond our directly owned international businesses in Asia, we do have significant and growing distributor-run businesses in other countries. We're focusing on expanding 2 partners in 4 regions. First, in Europe, where we have begun to build the foundation for long-term growth. Second, Latin America, including Brazil, Venezuela, Colombia, Panama, Chile and Peru. Third other Asia Pacific market such as Australia, Thailand and Indonesia. And fourth, the Middle East. These are in addition to the significant Global Travel Retail opportunities that continue to exist for Coach as the brand's recognition continues to grow globally. 
We've just reviewed our strategies to drive our growth at a double-digit pace, given the continuing strength of the Coach brand and our increasing global expansion. We have significant runway ahead of us, both in international -- both in North America, which remains a growing market and worldwide, while our focus on Men's and digital provides additional opportunities for growth.
At this time, I will turn it over to Jane Nielsen, our CFO, for further details on our financials and investment plans. Jane?

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Next, Lew. Lew and Mike have just taken you through the highlights and strategies. Let me now take you through some of the important financial details of our first quarter result. As a reminder, and as noted in our 8-K filing earlier this month, we've cha
componenttext:
Next, Lew. Lew and Mike have just taken you through the highlights and strategies. Let me now take you through some of the important financial details of our first quarter result. As a reminder, and as noted in our 8-K filing earlier this month, we've changed our segment reporting for FY '13 to a geographic focus, recognizing the expansion and growth of sales through our international market. This quarter, revenues increased 11%, with North America up 8% and international sales up 15%. Net income for the quarter totaled $221 million, up 3%, with earnings per diluted share of $0.77, up 6%. This compared to net income of $215 million and earnings per diluted share of $0.73 in the prior year's first quarter. Our operating income totaled $332 million, 3% above the $322 million reported last year, while operating margin was 28.6% versus 30.7%. This growth and our continued high level of profitability was achieved, while making unusual investments in our business, primarily related to our distributor acquisition, which we had previewed in our last conference call.
During this quarter, gross profit totaled $845 million versus $765 million a year ago, an increase of 11%. The gross margin rate was 72.8%, even with prior year, with our sourcing cost improvement offsetting the higher cost of inventory repurchased in our acquisition. As expected, our expense ratio in Q1 totaled 44.2% compared to the 42.8% reported in the year-ago quarter. Excluding the impact of distributor acquisition cost, we were able to gain leverage to EPS. As you know, our most significant investments is accelerate our international grow through the acquisition of domestic retail -- of the domestic retail operations of our key Asian distributors and the further development of infrastructure to support this global growth. We are also distorting our investment in the digital phase to expand and deepen our engagement with consumers.
Inventory levels at the end of the quarter were $598 million, 15% above the $520 million reported at the end of last year's Q1, consistent with our expectations given the repurchase of inventory from our newly acquired market. It will allow us to support distribution growth and to maximize this sale and holiday. 
Cash and short-term investments fitted [ph] $761 million, as compared with $848 million a year ago. During the first quarter, we repurchased and retired nearly 3.1 million shares of common stock at an average cost of $56.59, spending a total of $175 million. With only $87 million remaining of the previous authorization, the board authorized another $1.5 billion in share repurchases.
Net cash from operating activities in the first quarter was $202 million compared to $225 million last year during Q1. Free cash flow in the first quarter was an inflow of $146 million versus $194 million in the same period last year. Our CapEx spending were $56 million versus $31 million in the same quarter a year ago.
Consistent with our previous expectations and reflective of our global growth initiatives, we expect that CapEx this year will be in the area of $250 million, primarily due to new store openings and expansions across all geographies, elevating our store environment within our existing store and investments in the technology and infrastructure necessary to enable global expansion.
Looking at the balance sheet. The balance of 2013, the goals we articulated back in July have not changed. We remain mindful of balancing the impact of a weak global macroeconomic outlook with our optimism around our business. So when you're thinking about the year, our plans are in line with those outlined in our July call. 
First, and most generally, we continue to expect to achieve double-digit sales growth. Our FY '13 sales will be driven in part by low to mid-single-digit comps in North America for the year. As you know, our comparisons will be most challenging in second quarter given our extremely strong multi-year comp performance. However, we do expect the comps to strengthen in the second half. In addition, currency is likely to be more of a top line growth headwind in the first half of the year. 
Second, our gross margin is planned to improve modestly as channel mix and our sourcing initiatives continue to contribute to profitability. On balance, we expect gross margins to remain high and in the 73% range for the year. 
Third, on SG&A, international acquisitions alone will cause our expenses to rise at least 150 basis points for the year. 
Fourth, therefore, taken together, we would expect some compression in the operating margin to about 31%. Notably, we expect our core businesses to continue to deliver leveraged EPS. 
And fifth, our tax rate is likely to be in the area of 33% for the year as we further refine our international tax strategies.
In summary, we were pleased with our first quarter result, highlighted by double-digit top line growth and driven by strong comparable store sales in North America and China. Looking forward, we're accelerating our distribution plan to leverage the emerging market opportunity with a particular focus on China, exploring new geographies, capitalizing on the increasing popularity and recognition of the Coach brand with discerning consumers, both men and women globally. Importantly, we remain committed to achieving double-digit growth over our planning horizon. We have a business model that generates significant cash flow and we are in a position to invest in our brand, while continuing to return capital to shareholders. 
Now I'd like to open it up to Q&A.

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012

componenttext: I'm wondering if you can talk a little bit about China. We've seen a number of your peers indicate that sales, there have been a little bit difficult. And does that mean that you would expect after this year that you could actually see operating margins trend higher over time?

componenttext: Yes, for clarification, what we said is without the impact of the acquisitions, we would have had some leverage from sales to EPS growth. And our gross margin, as I called out, was impacted by acquisitions by about 30 basis points.

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good morning, Kimberly. Given the overall context of the markets and of course, our overall higher comp base, we are extremely pleased with the growth that we have shown in the quarter. And I think it's a stronger function of relevance of our product. And
componenttext: Good morning, Kimberly. Given the overall context of the markets and of course, our overall higher comp base, we are extremely pleased with the growth that we have shown in the quarter. And I think it's a stronger function of relevance of our product. And to the second part of your question, the performance of Legacy, as Mike touched on in his comments, Legacy is truly resonating globally, not just here in North America. And we're especially pleased with this performance in China where it is becoming a very strong second pillar for us alongside Madison. Madison has been since our launch in China with the take back of the business, a true iconic collection for us. It continues to be a very strong recruiting tool as such. And now Legacy is a second pillar and especially relevant with current Coach fans that are looking for a more subtle, more fashionable collection from a multicategory perspective. We're especially pleased in China with the performance of Men's and as well, even Outerwear where in certain locations we're seeing double-digit penetrations of Legacy Outerwear. So overall, a strong story.

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: I guess for Mike, a lot of questions surrounding the quarter was on the couponing side. So maybe just hoping you could just talk about the Facebook coupon at the Full Price stores and obviously, you still seem to have a lot of room to get towards your pea
componenttext: I guess for Mike, a lot of questions surrounding the quarter was on the couponing side. So maybe just hoping you could just talk about the Facebook coupon at the Full Price stores and obviously, you still seem to have a lot of room to get towards your peak conversion in traffic. Just trying to understand the thought process there? And similarly in the factory side, now you look back I guess you've had 2 or 3 quarters on the fair and square pricing, the couponing now back in the store, just give us some idea of your thought process now, what you've learned? And then maybe Lew just want to talk about the marketer opportunities maybe in Asia, x Japan. Obviously, your the market share leader here in the U.S. over 30% market share just wondering what are realistic targets you think Coach could have in Asia, x Japan over the next 5, 7 years?

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think we've got about 5 questions in there. Mike, why don't you take the first several.

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: I'll give it a crack. And let me address on the full price side, there's been some noise on the investor side around promotional activity. We actually saw a very healthy quarter in our full priced business. We were extremely pleased with Legacy and the pe
componenttext: I'll give it a crack. And let me address on the full price side, there's been some noise on the investor side around promotional activity. We actually saw a very healthy quarter in our full priced business. We were extremely pleased with Legacy and the performance of our business across Men's and Women's. And promotional activity is actually down. So what I think occurred out there, which was a pickup on your side a bit was we did experiment with some customer acquisitions, third-party opportunities within the digital space. And that created some noise in the marketplace. We'll continue to probe on that and experiment, but it's really not a large segment of our business. On the factory side, as we stated in Q4, we were going to take a more promotional stance in our stores around in-store marketing. And that proved to be very successful. And I might add there that we're really pleased on the factory side as we return to marketing tactics in-store. We're able to maintain very high margin rates consistent with prior year and get the productivity levels back.

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mike. As we go to market share opportunities. I'd mentioned before, we had 17% market share in Japan where We are the #2 share. It was -- it would show you to suggest that in China, we could have that market share. But we would not be contempt
componenttext: Thank you, Mike. As we go to market share opportunities. I'd mentioned before, we had 17% market share in Japan where We are the #2 share. It was -- it would show you to suggest that in China, we could have that market share. But we would not be contempt anything less on over time. So we do believe as the market develops, Coach is particularly well positioned for the emerging middle class in China. Victor, touched on our business and our consumers. They still have over a 90% repurchase intent. We feel very optimistic that in the emerging markets, we can develop very strong leadership positions. In more developed markets, we think it's more realistic to look at 10% as an aspirational goal where in certain markets today, we have 5% and 7%. Victor, you want to expand on that?

componenttext: Can you talk a little bit about Legacy and the customer base that you're seeing? Do you view it a as new customer? Is that a lapse customer? Or is your core Coach customer that's very enthused about Legacy?

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's really all of the above. And it varies a lot by market. What we're finding is that some of the Legacy styles that are extremely reminiscent of the styles that were in existence 20 or 30 years ago are particularly appealing to an existing consumer, th
componenttext: It's really all of the above. And it varies a lot by market. What we're finding is that some of the Legacy styles that are extremely reminiscent of the styles that were in existence 20 or 30 years ago are particularly appealing to an existing consumer, the larger bags. At the same time, the smaller bags are doing, which are trend-right, are doing very well with our younger consumers. Overall, we're finding that we are appealing to new consumers, existing consumers and lapse consumers. It all depends on the market and the circumstance.

componenttext: We're really -- I would say in exploration mode on the flash side. It is a very targeted program with discrete audience of factory-only consumers. We're targeting pricing, margin structure that we love, response rate and performance that we control. And we'll continue to use. This is just an extension of us moving into the digital world and leveraging it across channels and across customer types in a good way.

componenttext: Sure. The only place where we had experimented and tested is in Japan. headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's actually a very substantial opportunity as consumers are looking for convenience and they're also looking for limited edition factory product. And again, just to reiterate, this is a focus on consumers who only purchase in factory stores. We do not o
componenttext: It's actually a very substantial opportunity as consumers are looking for convenience and they're also looking for limited edition factory product. And again, just to reiterate, this is a focus on consumers who only purchase in factory stores. We do not offer this opportunity to full priced consumers. So what we're doing is we're leveraging the opportunity among existing brand-loyal Coach factory store consumers, give them the opportunity for a time-limited circumstance to buy factory product at a great price.

componenttext: It's J.C. for Paul. One question and one clarification. The first question is on Legacy, and how we should think about how this line would transition into the factory channel and what the timing on that would be? And how does that compare transition Poppy from full priced to factor? And then on the clarification, I think you said you gross margins on factory were flat, and I'm not sure you meant operating margin but if you could just clarify that and if you can give us gross margin in your other channels as well?

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'll take most of that. Our Legacy development today is focused solely on full priced across Men's and Women's. We are in the very, very early days of development. We have tremendous innovation and newness coming into the marketplace there across si
componenttext: Sure. I'll take most of that. Our Legacy development today is focused solely on full priced across Men's and Women's. We are in the very, very early days of development. We have tremendous innovation and newness coming into the marketplace there across silhouette, fabrication. There is not any need for us to think about Legacy as a factory platform. In fact, we're looking at newness and elevation within factory Legacy as we head into the fourth quarter, third and fourth quarter of '13 and into '14 where we have exciting platforms there, leather and fabric-based. So Legacy is really a full priced proposition going forward. And when I was speaking to margin, what I was talking about margin rate in factory stores during the quarter, holding its own against the change in the promotional strategy, which we're very pleased with.

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Wanted to ask you about marketing. I think Mike had mentioned it in the prepared remarks, mid-November marketing plan. How are you guys philosophically, strategically thinking about marketing plans? You've got 2 kind of arguably very different, very impor
componenttext: Wanted to ask you about marketing. I think Mike had mentioned it in the prepared remarks, mid-November marketing plan. How are you guys philosophically, strategically thinking about marketing plans? You've got 2 kind of arguably very different, very important initiatives, both the Legacy and the Men's, which are a little bit new for the brand. How important is the marketing to get the word out to consumers to bring them into the stores? And what are some of the strategies around that? And I also wanted to ask, within the Legacy business, are you seeing any differentiation in terms of the success of higher price points or lower price points or different type or products within the Legacy business in the early days?

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, first your general question on marketing. We are approaching, both -- we're approaching Legacy as our new collections and our collections in the dual-gender manner. If you look at our print ads and look at all of our digital advertising, you'll see
componenttext: Well, first your general question on marketing. We are approaching, both -- we're approaching Legacy as our new collections and our collections in the dual-gender manner. If you look at our print ads and look at all of our digital advertising, you'll see both the dual-gender products, as well as Women's products, the Men's products, featured in a lifestyle manner with people who personify the Coach brand. And so we have a layered approach on the marketing. More specifically, when we think of marketing, it's not only advertising, but it's store windows, store environment. And when you visit our stores today, you'll see Men's presence in most of our store windows. You will also see in our flagship locations a very strong head-to-toe lifestyle presentation. And we feel quite good that our ability to convey a broader world of Coach that's more modern, more emotional and more relevant.

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Well, just to build on that, in terms of marketing, where I would point to is our efforts to enhance our store environments, not only through window presentation, but in-store environments. We did make a strong investment going into the year and through t
componenttext: Well, just to build on that, in terms of marketing, where I would point to is our efforts to enhance our store environments, not only through window presentation, but in-store environments. We did make a strong investment going into the year and through the quarter in the top 100 stores. In full priced of we got there. Our flagship stores outperformed in the quarter, driven by, I think, a more comprehensive Legacy presentation, including Men's that really cut through. We'll continue to build on that. And what we're seeing out there, including in key department store locations, tremendous appetite or range of price points and product offer and handbags within Legacy and all our collections. We have to continue to take advantage of that from a marketing and positioning standpoint in the marketplace.

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Jessica Web.
componenttext: Our next question is from Jessica Web.

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could give us more detail about how much of an impact of the Asian acquisitions had improvement on gross margins, as well as how much benefited from the sourcing initiative and the channel mix?
componenttext: I was wondering if you could give us more detail about how much of an impact of the Asian acquisitions had improvement on gross margins, as well as how much benefited from the sourcing initiative and the channel mix?

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Jessica, what you saw is that we had a 72.8 [ph] margin, about even with prior year. And what we're calling out is that our sourcing initiative and improvement there, we're able to offset about 30 basis points of pressure from the repurchase inventory in
componenttext: Jessica, what you saw is that we had a 72.8 [ph] margin, about even with prior year. And what we're calling out is that our sourcing initiative and improvement there, we're able to offset about 30 basis points of pressure from the repurchase inventory in the acquisition. So excluding acquisitions, we would have seen gross margins up 30 basis points. On the cost side, what we're seeing is through these acquisitions that we expect as I called out in the prepared remarks about 150 basis points of pressure on the SG&A line from the acquisition as we move through the year. At least in the first half, it eases in the second half.

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Very much consistent with prior years. Little bit of new ones by store attribute, so you'll see some distortion in higher price points, in flagship stores and more balanced in primary stores. We are making a stronger play in what I would call tech accesso
componenttext: Very much consistent with prior years. Little bit of new ones by store attribute, so you'll see some distortion in higher price points, in flagship stores and more balanced in primary stores. We are making a stronger play in what I would call tech accessories, that's kind of obvious given what's going on in the marketplace. It's also a price point opportunity, color opportunity. So you'll see us go after that in both channels, frankly. And we feel like from a gifting standpoint, having Men's and Women's more bold in more stores offers us a nice advantage this holiday versus prior years.

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012

componenttext: I think Lew touched on that earlier. We are releasing a broad response for Legacy across existing and new consumers. Terrific response to Legacy in the department store channel where we've seen tremendous impacts on leather-based and penetrations as leather go up. The other nice thing about Legacy from a handbag standpoint is this landing right in our sweet spots in terms of average unit retail. Right in that $300 range, but again some headroom to move up with elevated product and select stores going forward.

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Historically, it's been a great strength of Coach that you haven't been very reliant on the department store channel to drive your growth. However, it is an important customer phasing channel and important for the brand given how many customers are going
componenttext: Historically, it's been a great strength of Coach that you haven't been very reliant on the department store channel to drive your growth. However, it is an important customer phasing channel and important for the brand given how many customers are going through department stores in the U.S. and how the accessories business is growing just proportionately within that channel. I just visit your new Herrell in basis, which looks sensational and I was wondering, is this kind of a reinvigorated commitment to the presentation to the content in that channel? And are you looking perhaps to defend your market share a little more aggressively in that channel given the success of the category there?

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: You said it all. We are, first of all, we believe in the department store channel in North America. We believe in our partners there. We believe in our leadership position there. We have really put our noses into that business. We understand the competiti
componenttext: You said it all. We are, first of all, we believe in the department store channel in North America. We believe in our partners there. We believe in our leadership position there. We have really put our noses into that business. We understand the competitive set well. I think the Harold Square effort, which was led by Lew and the management team here speak to our commitment in the channel. We're going to school there. We will be relentless. We will look for opportunity and we'll manage our business one customer at a time in the same way that we manage our business in all of our other channels.

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: We're really looking to optimize productivity there. Sell-in, things like replenishment and in the opportunity to maintain consistency in the channel, newness, potential product development opportunities within the channel. It's across all areas. What we
componenttext: We're really looking to optimize productivity there. Sell-in, things like replenishment and in the opportunity to maintain consistency in the channel, newness, potential product development opportunities within the channel. It's across all areas. What we want to manage there is focus on the locations that we're in, how to make that more productive and to point our inventory into the right stores at the right time and turn that business and move it forward.

componenttext: The follow-up on the department store strategy that you were just mentioning. On the inventory side, at this point, do you have enough inventory in that channel? headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Yes, the big opportunity other department store side, particularly with Macy's but I think with others, too, is to really focus on DDI and to focus on getting into a replenishment business across key styles that we can own and manage. We own the inventory
componenttext: Yes, the big opportunity other department store side, particularly with Macy's but I think with others, too, is to really focus on DDI and to focus on getting into a replenishment business across key styles that we can own and manage. We own the inventory. We're working very closely. As we look into Q2 from a readiness standpoint, we feel like we have a very good pipe. We are being more conservative with our shift into that channel but as we see the business move and we see traction, we have the opportunity to chase and to replenish into that business in a very productive way.

componenttext: I'm sorry, in Men's list, the reality for us here is, while we push North America standpoint, we pushed Men's into about 100 stores in what we would call a significant way. We now have Men's in all stores, either through CBS or in some opening assortment way going into the holiday season, which I think provides us further opportunity within the quarter.

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: I think on the met side, as I touched on earlier, while we haven't broken out specifically what the Men's contribution is, it is a positive driver from a productivity standpoint. And absolutely, we are looking from a format standpoint, as well as within e
componenttext: I think on the met side, as I touched on earlier, while we haven't broken out specifically what the Men's contribution is, it is a positive driver from a productivity standpoint. And absolutely, we are looking from a format standpoint, as well as within existing locations how we can get Men's product into our stores. I mentioned Pentagon City in my prepared remarks. That's a store where we've expanded and relocated in a mall to add Men's store within side-by-side our women store. While we've essentially seen the Men's the business come from 0 in the prior store to a very significant Men's contribution relative to Women's. So we're looking at that as a concept for us to potentially expand further in top locations to build out in addition to adding Men's into all stores going forward.

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: And to your question on e-commerce site, as we discussed, at the beginning of next month, we will go live. E-commerce in China, which follows up our first international site in Japan. Right now, we're very focused on transforming our informational sites a
componenttext: And to your question on e-commerce site, as we discussed, at the beginning of next month, we will go live. E-commerce in China, which follows up our first international site in Japan. Right now, we're very focused on transforming our informational sites across our other direct to Asian markets into fuller marketing sites, including deep leverage of mobile and iPad apps. As well as from the possibility of partnering with our distributor partners in other markets and looking at future development in the e-commerce space.

componenttext: Mike, I was wondering if you can help us understand as we look ahead to the holiday quarter, how you guys would be planning the promotions like the best customer events and what have you and how that's plan relative to last year so that there's less confusion in the holiday quarter versus the prior quarter? And then also related to that, could you give us a sense of the complexion of handbags in terms of distribution between the bucket of below $400 and over $400, I think you guys talk about in the past, just wondering what's going on with that,.

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. On the promotional side across full price and factory channel, very consistent with prior years. I think the only new ones out there is the method of delivery. What we put in the male, what we're doing digitally and how we might play with regard to
componenttext: Sure. On the promotional side across full price and factory channel, very consistent with prior years. I think the only new ones out there is the method of delivery. What we put in the male, what we're doing digitally and how we might play with regard to third-party opportunities. But our plans today are very consistent with last year. In terms of mix on products, penetration is over $400 were essentially the same. In Q1, I think you've heard me this morning speak about what I'm sensing as an opportunity for more elevated products, which I think may have an impact on that price hearing going forward. We did see some improvement in ADT overall, which we're very pleased with. And we think we're extremely well positioned from a gifting and pricing standpoint across all channels as we head into the holiday quarter.

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Lew. We've really are well into our 4-year plan that we've articulated that we've lapped about a year ago. And that shift has benefited us as we move more and more of our production into countries outside of China, Vietnam, Indonesia, other countr
componenttext: Thanks, Lew. We've really are well into our 4-year plan that we've articulated that we've lapped about a year ago. And that shift has benefited us as we move more and more of our production into countries outside of China, Vietnam, Indonesia, other countries. And that involves both finished goods and raw materials. So that shift has continued as the kind of the mix has offset the actual pressure that we've seen in labor. So obviously, as we look forward, there is a lot of uncertainty about what our labor costs will be around Asia and around the manufacturing base. So that's something we'll have to continue to pay attention to as we look to the future.

headline: Coach, Inc., Q1 2013 Earnings Call, Oct 23, 2012
componenttextpreview: Overall, we've been able -- raw material has seen hit a spike about 2 years ago. It dropped. We've been successful and we have a great raw material team that really spand Asia and Europe and not only addresses leather, but also justice hardware. We've had
componenttext: Overall, we've been able -- raw material has seen hit a spike about 2 years ago. It dropped. We've been successful and we have a great raw material team that really spand Asia and Europe and not only addresses leather, but also justice hardware. We've had very aggressive posture of taking positions we need to optimizing raw material costs. So just about 60% of our cost of goods when you look at our hand but leather goods, while our expertise and credibility there, including creating new sourcing basis in our new countries where we're doing manufacturing, which cuts our logistics expenses has all kind of contributed to keeping those cost in check and keeping us in a good point. But is work well for us. We'll continue to strive to make it work as we look at the future.
